awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Genetic-epidemiology framework for malaria mosquito and disease
awd_abstract_narration:
Malaria is one of the deadliest diseases affecting mankind. The disease, which is caused by the protozoan Plasmodium parasites, is spread between humans via the bite of infected adult female mosquitoes and creates severe public health and socio-economic burdens in regions inhabited by almost half of the world’s population. Each year, malaria infects an average of over 230 million people and causes over 400,000 deaths (mostly in children under the age of five) in endemic areas globally. The widescale use of insecticides-based interventions, notably in the form of long-lasting insecticidal (LLINs) nets and indoor residual spraying (IRS), during the period 2000-2015, has resulted in a dramatic decrease in malaria burden in endemic areas, prompting a concerted global effort to eradicate the disease by 2040.  Unfortunately since 2015, the malaria mosquito has developed widespread resistance to all five chemicals used in LLINs and IRS.  Insecticide resistance and changes in climatic variables are two of the main impediments to malaria eradication. Since LLINs and IRS are the cornerstone interventions for malaria control, one of the most crucial challenges in the malaria ecology community is to determine whether insecticide resistance affects malaria epidemiology. This project will use mathematical modeling approaches, backed by novel empirical data collected in the laboratory as well as in the field, to provide realistic insight into the impact, control and mitigation of the impediments. The project will provide strategies for realistically achieving malaria eradication using existing insecticides-based control resources.  The methodologies and results generated will be made available for broad application, and for studying the transmission dynamics and control of other vector-borne diseases such as chikungunya, dengue, Lyme disease, West Nile virus and Zika virus. The project will support the training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as the participation of local high school students and teachers.

The project will develop a genetic-epidemiology modeling framework for providing realistic insight into the malaria transmission dynamics and control, subject to insecticide pressure. The modeling framework extends the classical Ross-Macdonald compartmental modeling framework for malaria by adding, inter alia, the detailed lifecycle and population genetics of malaria mosquitoes (i.e., genetics of insecticide resistance) and the complex host-vector-parasite interactions. The models will allow for the assessment of the impacts of local changes in climatic variables (notably temperature) on the population abundance of the malaria mosquitoes by genotype. The approach of modeling the host-vector-parasite dynamics, in the context of malaria, will offer significant advances in applied mathematics and numerical analysis, particularly in designing and applying dynamical systems and numerical discretization theories and techniques for studying the transmission dynamics and control of diseases caused by vectors (such as mosquitoes and ticks). Specifically, PIs will (i) design a modeling framework for assessing the role of insecticide resistance on the fitness costs of insecticide resistance at different environmental conditions, (ii) evaluate the role of insecticide resistance on the ability of resistant mosquitoes to transmit malaria and (iii) assess the role of natural environmental factors on the abundance of insecticide resistance genotypes and how it relates to malaria incidence. This project will generate hard-to-get data on the fitness costs of insecticide resistance and impact of resistance on malaria parasite development in mosquitoes, which are so invaluable to the design and parametrization of realistic mathematical models for studying the role of insecticide resistance on the dynamics of malaria mosquitoes and disease. This will provide a realistic framework for the design and testing of resistance management strategies for malaria-endemic areas that only have a small chemical arsenal left to fight the disease. Ultimately, this project will generate conditions, in parameter space, for the effective control or elimination of malaria using existing insecticides-based resources, thereby contributing to the global malaria eradication efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Background: The project addressed the problem of the transmission dynamics and control of malaria, a major parasitic disease transmitted between humans via the bite of an infected adult female Anopheles mosquito.  affecting over half the human race.  Dramatic successes have been recorded in the fight against malaria following the widescale and widespread use of chemical insecticides to control mosquitoes during the period between the year 2000 to 2015. Unfortunately, the wide-scale and widespread use of mosquito control interventions have also resulted in widespread mosquito resistance to all the available chemical insecticides used in vector control.  A major open question in the mosquito ecology and wider malaria community is whether insecticide resistance actually impacts malaria epidemiology. This project aimed to settle this open question via the use of a novel mathematical modeling framework, backed by novel empirical data collected in the laboratory as well as in a major malaria-endemic region of the world.  We assembled a team of researchers with diverse and complementary expertise in modeling (Gumel and Mohammed-Awel) and entomology (Huijben and Paaijmans) to address three well-chosen specific aims centered on assessing the impacts of fitness costs and benefits of insecticide resistance and quantifying the impact of natural environmental conditions on the abundance of resistance genotypes and the effectiveness of insecticide-based malaria control interventions.

The project outputs contributed by the four Principal Investigators (PIs) are summarized below:

(a)  University of Maryland (PI Gumel) 

PI Gumel trained two Arizona State University (ASU) graduate students (S. Brozak and E. Iboi; when PI Gumel was at ASU) on modeling the impacts of insecticide resistance on the population ecology of malaria mosquitoes. They published 3 research papers stemming from this work. Five undergraduate students and five high school students were trained by PI Gumel during the grant period. PI Gumel published five research papers, in addition to editing one book and publishing a book chapter on topics relevant to this project. Moreover, PI Gumel co-organized (with PI Mohammed-Awel and Lauren Childs) a workshop on” Mathematics of Malaria Transmission Dynamics". PI Gumel gave several plenary and invited research lectures at national and international conferences, received several prestigious research honors and recognitions during the three-year grant period. 

(b) Morgan State University (PI Mohammed-Awel)

PI Mohammed-Awel trained Valdosta State University undergraduate student Christian Evans (when PI Mohammed-Awel was at Valdosta State University) on modeling insecticide resistance in mosquitoes. PI Mohammed-Awel assisted Evans to publish a research paper in scientific journal. The students also presented the results of the project at two regional conferences. Morgan State University undergraduate student Kaelah Bryant was trained by PI Mohammed-Awel (at Morgan State University) on modeling drug treatment against malaria. The student presented the work (which was a senior undergraduate research project) at the Mathematics Department, Morgan State University, in Spring 2023. PI Mohammed-Awel supervised the master’s thesis of Morgan State University graduate student Muswe Mundemba on modeling the impacts of vaccination and treatment on the transmission dynamics and control of malaria (the thesis work was completed in December 2023). PI Mohammed-Awel published five research papers and a book chapter (on topics relevant to the research project) during the three-year grant period. Also, PI Mohammed-Awel’s work on this grant was featured in a SIAM News. Furthermore, PI Mohammed-Awel gave nine research talks at national and international conferences during the three-year grant period. Moreover, PI Mohammed-Awel co-organized (with PI Gumel) a malaria workshop, co-organized two special sessions at the mathematics joint meetings (in 2023 and 2024) and received an award for research contribution at Morgan State.

(c)  Arizona State University (PIs Huijben and Paaijmans)

PIs Huijben and Paaijmans trained graduate students Brook Jensen and Joshua Kalmouni on data collection of insecticide susceptibility at various temperatures. Brook Jensen was further trained on modeling selection for resistance at waning insecticide dosages. Brook Jensen presented her research findings at seven regional, national and international meetings, published one first-authored paper with several in preparation, and obtained five awards and fellowships during the grant period. Joshua Kalmouni presented his research findings at three national meetings, and one first-authored paper has been accepted with several in preparation. He also obtained three awards during the grant period. Additionally, five undergraduate students were trained during this grant period, and PIs Huijben and Paaijmans supervised two honors theses (Chance Spurlin and Joshua Ain) on the research project. PI Huijben published six research papers on topics relevant to the research project during the three-year grant period, and gave 13 research talks at national and international conferences. Moreover, PI Huijben co-organized a workshop at the American Institute of Mathematics on “Multi-scale modeling of malaria”. PI Paaijmans published three research papers, with several in preparation, gave four research talks at national and international conferences, and was named Honorary Professor at the Wits Research Institute for Malaria in South Africa.

 


Last Modified: 08/06/2024
Modified by: Abba B Gumel
